channel.title: QEMU Advent Calendar 2016
channel.description: The latest disk images from the QEMU Advent Calendar.

item.title: Day 20 - Fast and easy to use OS
item.description: Day 20 features an open source OS that specifically targets personal computing. Fast, simple to use and yet very powerful.

item.title: Day 19 - Boot sector gaming, part 3
item.description: Can you fit a game with complex rules into a boot sector with 512 bytes? Today's goodie will give you the anser...

item.title: Day 18 - OS written in alternative language
item.description: Most operating systems are nowadays written in C / C++, but what happens if you use another modern programming language instead? Open the door of day 18 to find out...

item.title: Day 17 - The greenish prompt
item.description: Today the advent calendar features a modern operating system designed for devices that have to conserve power, memory, and storage.

item.title: Day 16 - Compile before booting
item.description: What happens if your bootloader is a C compiler? You could boot source code that you just compiled during booting...

item.title: Day 15 - May the Forth be with you
item.description: Today we've got a game written in Forth, running on top of Open Firmware.

item.title: Day 14 - Unikernel demo
item.description: If you just want to run one appliance in your VM, why should you bother wasting resources with a whole full-blown guest OS? Today we feature a webserver demo with a unikernel guest OS that helps you to build small and performing applications.

item.title: Day 13 - Turtles all the way down
item.description: What happens if you start a VM inside of another VM which is running inside of another VM, ... etc.? Open the door of day 13 to find out.

item.title: Day 12 - Boot sector gaming, part 2
item.description: Move blocks and clear rows - in less than 512 bytes!

item.title: Day 11 - A secure framework
item.description: Today we present you a tool kit for building highly secure special-purpose operating systems.

item.title: Day 10 - QEMU gaming
item.description: Have fun with a nice vintage DOS game that runs in QEMU.

item.title: Day 9 - Fast and compact, part 2
item.description: Today you can have a look at another operating system where the kernel has been written completely in assembly! It boots fast, has a small memory footprint, and maybe even more important: The disk image contains some games!

item.title: Day 8 - Failsafe invasion
item.description: An alien invasion that even continues after a power failure? Check day 8 of the advent calendar when you are ready to defend the earth!

item.title: Day 7 - Boot sector gaming, part 1
item.description: A game written in less than 512 bytes, with graphics and sound... is it possible? Open the door of day 7 to find out.

item.title: Day 6 - Fast and compact, part 1
item.description: Today, we've got an operating system that has been written entirely in assembly, designed to be fast and compact.

item.title: Day 5 - Fun with stacks
item.description: This day is about stacks - with regards to the output that the program shows on the screen, and with regards to the programming language that has been used.

item.title: Day 4 - Redmond compatible
item.description: Another day, another operating system - this time with the goal of being compatible with one of the well established operating systems.

item.title: Day 3 - 16-bit retro GUI
item.description: After the text mode retro experience on the first day, there is now a 16-bit retro GUI experience for you to explore in the calendar today.

item.title: Day 2 - Alternative desktop experience
item.description: Enjoy an original, alternative, easy-to-use open source desktop operating system.

item.title: Day 1 - 16-bit text mode retro feeling
item.description: It's now December 1st, so the first image of the QEMU advent calendar 2016 is available now, bringing you some 16-bit text mode retro feeling to enjoy.
